Fields.DialogueText: Fräulein Emden! What's the status of the search?
I've dispersed Aufklärer to look for my Studenten.
I've also been thinking about some Aufwertungen in the meantime.

Fields.MenuText: Oh? What type of upgrades are we talking about?
We don't need upgrades. You do good work already.
I have a few suggestions I'd like to put in!

Fields.DialogueText: Various Dinge for being neither seen nor heard.
Are you certain of this, Kapitän? The sheer Anzahl of Nixen threatening us would be reason enough.
Oh? I'd love to hear about them after we get the basics taken care of!
What are the first upgrades you have in mind?
Well, with it, we are more likely to sneak into an operational area before my Studenten can be moved out.
*ALARM*
I'd like to see this in action sooner rather than later!
@BATTLE
Besides, they are training to be engineers. It would give them something to study!
Have you read the recent papers concerning the Nixen's methods of observation and detection, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Sure.
They're on my to-do list.
No. Please don't make me.

Fields.DialogueText: I have the sense that they're mostly speculative.
Unavoidably so. But the speculation is based on technologies currently under human development - it's not superstition and guesswork.
And those are technologies you want to replicate?
Nein. Well, eventually, ja - but for now I'm thinking about ways to baffle them.
A few years ago, Dutch researchers made a bit of a breakthrough with electromagnetic wave absorbers. I won't get into fine details unless you ask-
Not right this minute.
- But I believe that we could engineer a substance that could be applied to the hull, almost like paint, that might reduce the risk of being detected by reflected radio waves.
And that untested technology is appropriate to our mission how...?
Any leads yet?
Not yet, but it's suspected that possibly our Bibel thieves kidnapped my Studenten. Any word on the whereabouts of the Offizier who was with them?
Crickets, as ever. You don't think Santos was involved as well, seeking revenge?
That is within the realm of possibility, but what would a Sammler want with a group of engineering Studenten?
What would artifact thieves want with them?
Reconnaisance? They could blend in just about anywhere on a Studienreise. They could have been kidnapped and put to thieving use.

Fields.MenuText: Santos collects objects of curious value. He could very well use them for the same purpose.
I wonder if they are elsewhere, being trained as assassins?
Maybe they are being put to work in a factory building military equipment.

Fields.DialogueText: So far, our Geheimdienst has found nothing tying them to the Amerikas. That doesn't guarantee they won't end up there eventually.
What a frightening thought!
That is a thought! I have no doubt my Kontakte will leave no Stein auf dem Anderen in their search.
*ALARM*
Let's make this Kampf quick, Kapitän. We can't waste a Augenblick in our search!
@BATTLE
Damn it! Morganas. I know we shouldn't be jumping to conclusions, but what other leads do we have?
This paint is as thick as anything.
That's why Flugzeuge can't use it. It's far too heavy for flight.
Whoever figures that out first is going to get a nasty drop on the rest of the world.
All the more reason to find my Klasse! Their studies involved precisely that Problem.
Were they close to solving it?
Vielleicht. My Vorlesung was well received... at least one of them may have made some connections. Perhaps even a Durchbruch.

Fields.MenuText: You're a good teacher, all right.
We can't let the enemy get their hands on this.
They're that smart?

Fields.DialogueText: But if my teachings were used against the Reich and its people... Kapitän, I could not bear it!
It cannot fall into the hands of foreign powers... and especially not the Nixen.
Every Student is smart, Kapitän. It is the teacher that must uncover how to reach them. I have full faith in their abilities... na all Kanten.
So where do we go from here?
We are going to Denemark next, but first we must pick up some Duuven!
Why pigeons?
In the Taunus the apothecarian Julius Neubronner trained Duuven to carry medicine over town.
He invented a Kamera small enough for Duuven to carry and take pictures on a delayed timer. Belgier have trained similar Duuven to come to Schiffe.
So we're using pigeons to take pictures for us?
Ja.
*ALARM*
Well, I guess we know now that the paint doesn't repel Morganas.
@BATTLE
Perhaps when we rescue my Studenten, I shall make that their next Projekt.
These pigeons sure are messy.
It's a small price to pay for covert Luftphotographie.
Schiffsdame Emden, the eleven are ready to board.

Fields.MenuText: What are they doing here?
Aren't there appelbeignets here for our guests?
Why weren't these thieves incarcerated already?

Fields.DialogueText: We're seeing if they were involved with the disappearance. However, their willingness to meet with us suggests that they weren't.
One step ahead of you, Kapitän. I already had the Smutje retrieve them for me.
It is our decision to make now. That is why I am slightly more willing to trust them.
Don't interrogate the group too harshly, Leutnant. Perhaps offer them a bite to eat first. Even if they don't know the whereabouts of my Studenten, they might still be able to help us.
Jawohl, Schiffsdame Emden.
*ALARM*
Really? I was looking forward to taking part in this interrogation.
You're not alone. And yet, it's probably best that we ensure the Schiff not be blown to Fetzen.
Yes, yes. You'd know best.
@BATTLE
We have the Resultate of the Verhör, Schiffsdame Emden!
Das ist wunderbar! Let's hear the Resultate so we can analyze the data that we have.
Our thieves were not involved in the disappearance of your students.
Figures...
I suspected as much.
Why were they so willing to board in the first place?
They have offered to assist in the retrieval once we discover the class's whereabouts.
Lovt Gott!

Fields.MenuText: This is an unusual turn of events.
More mouths to feed...
Hopefully they'll be able to get your students back.

Fields.DialogueText: Die Wege des Herrn sind unergründlich.
Now, Kapitän! That's no way to treat those who have offered their help.
They were able to steal one of Germany's most prized Bücher. I don't doubt their ability.
Maybe they can help us with the Morganas as well.
They might be able to steal something from those Hexen.
There's no shortage of Morganas. The minute they prove false, we'll test that theory.
No need to be so unforgiving. They have been forgiven already for the Gutenberg.
*ALARM*
We'd better put our money where our mouths are. Forgiveness isn't much use to them if they're dead.
Now is not the time for a theologische Diskussion, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
I'm surprised you're not more impatient to start the search.
But while we are in the Hafen, why not add on a few more upgrades? A bit of maintenance is delightfully refreshing for the Seele.
I thought crafting with your hands was good for the soul?
Crafting is an expression and everyone should be able to express themselves one way or another. What is an upgrade but the purest Form of crafting?
Obwohl... I should go back to creating more Buddelschiffe soon. The Lady Hood is getting rather impatient about her Order being late.
What are we upgrading on the ship right now?
First, the Scheinwerfer are being upgraded. Spot and search lights.
Are you happy with the state of detection systems?
I... am giving that some thought. I'm well aware improvements aren't so easy to come by.
What about arms?
I am a Leichter Kreuzer, and such things are constantly on my mind. We need to consider fuel Effizienz over blazing big Kanonen.
Having said this... I know some Schiffsdamen like to kroppen themselves on their arms or their speed, but I think Training should be given its due.

Fields.MenuText: Explain to me again how education gives you an advantage over weaponry?
Detection systems aren't technically weapons, though.
Maybe the thieves can steal us some new toys.

Fields.DialogueText: If you're educated about the Feind, you save Geld by specializing accordingly and omitting unnecessary upgrades.
Sehr wahr, although though they can be valuable tools. Knowledge can save a factory's worth of Granaten.
That might be a possibility, Kapitän, but stealing is generally moralisch wrong.
*ALARM*
Well... time to make do what we currently have.
You don't have to sound so unimpressed!
@BATTLE
Make no mistake, I am. And so is the Universität of Göttingen. They've set aside a considerable chunk of their Dotation to fund our efforts.
Emden, what are you doing?
I am praying for the safe return of my Studenten. I miss them so... I hope they are all right. I must have faith in Gott.
In Zeiten großer uncertainty, I ask Him for strength. I suppose some Schiffsdamen believe that their own strength and courage will carry them through difficult Zeiten... But where I end, He begins.

Fields.MenuText: You might be confusing strength for arrogance and overconfidence. You should hear some of the tales I've heard.
Some Belles pretend to be confident because they don't want it to be known that they are secretly scared.
What's with the wine?

Fields.DialogueText: Even if their strength is an Illusion, it gets them through the difficult Zeiten.
Being afraid isn't always effizient. Schiffsdamen must put on a tough face to encourage their Mannschaft to fight.
This is wine for the Abendmahl which the Pastor blesses. It's not Apfelwein.
Schiffsdame Emden, we have received Informationen that your Studenten were last spotted off the Küste von Schanghai.
I've been there before. I wonder if this is for revenge...
Let's not jump to any conclusions! Whatever the reason, we have to rescue them from being shanghaied.
The only way to find out is to... Kapitän. I ought to let you nachsitzen for that.
I outrank you.
*ALARM*
How convenient. Ik mutt mien Gall utspeeien!
@BATTLE
... Richtig. When we get under way, we're going to have several thousand Meilen to discuss what constitutes a Machtmissbrauch.
I did visit China, years ago. I wonder if this has anything to do with that Törn...
What did you do in China?
Personally, I just cruised up to Nanking and Schanghai. However, a previous Inkarnationen of Emden have been involved in many battles in China, disrupting trade.
How's that?
Oh, as their old Imperium declined, just about everyone was throwing their weight around in China. Britain, Germany, Japan...
Perhaps I'm still blamed for some of the sins of my Ahnen. Perhaps that's why my Studenten were taken.

Fields.MenuText: Then you think they are holding your students for ransom?
What if your students were traded?
What if they are on their way to Russia?

Fields.DialogueText: They very well could be. I do hope my Studenten are safe.
O Gommes nee!
Why would the Sowjets be involved? Is there something you're not telling me, Kapitän?
In any case, the pictures your pigeons took in the area are being developed. We will have an answer soon enough.
We'd better. The Universität, the NSLB... to say nothing of the Familien of the Studenten. The Reich is supporting our venture precisely because there are so many waiting on an answer.
*ALARM*
Well, we all have our priorities. But my Studenten come first. Now, let us clear the way to them!
@BATTLE
No...
I'm sure it doesn't exactly look good for the government to have their best and brightest go missing.
Kapitän! The Offizier who was escorting my Studenten has been found!
Are they with him?
No Informationen yet, but he is alive! And we finally have a lead on him... Lovt Gott!
Have the crew bring him aboard, right away!
Jawohl, Kapitän!

Fields.MenuText: I wonder what happened to the officer?
How did they end up over here in Shanghai?
Are we certain he wasn't involved?

Fields.DialogueText: My guess is that he was kidnapped along with the Studenten. How did he manage to escape?
Good question! Let's be gentle and not interrogate this poor Offizier who has already been through enough.
Nein. But we have him right where we need him. We will get to the bottom of this.
What's taking the crew so long?
Patience, Kapitän. The Mannschaft must make sure the escape of the Offizier wasn't a trap of some sort.
These types of situations must be treated as if you were sweeping a Minenfeld. I teach my Mannschaft that haste is not encouraged in these Szenarien.
*ALARM*
But we must finish this Kampf quickly. Lose the escort and we lose the Studenten!
@BATTLE
So, are the students still in China?
I'm afraid not, Kapitän.
Meine armen Studenten! What could any evildoers want with them?
It was told to me by the villagers of Nanking that the Studenten were taken to Nagoya to work on a new type of Flugzeuge.
Japan's behind this? But they're a German war ally.
Not Japan, per se. But certain corporate interests are reportedly keenly interested in adapting that stealth paint to their Flugzeuge.
And if the students were working on just that problem...
It means they were closer than we could have anticipated.
Or some ambitious Industriebaron thinks they were.
But Emden, earlier you stated that ferrite-based stealth paint is too heavy for planes.
Rivets once caused too much drag on Flugzeugen, but the Japaner found a way around the Problem. I suspect they are trying to do the same with the Farbe. Perhaps an adhesive-based solution...

Fields.MenuText: How did you manage to escape?
Emden, do you think the students are capable of installing this technology?
How would the ferrite-based paint be improved upon?

Fields.DialogueText: It couldn't have been simple.
Those Studenten are some of the brightest and most capable I've ever encountered. I do not doubt their ability.
I would have to refer to my Chemiebücher to find your answer, Kapitän. Lots to do with Kohlenstaub.
Why did the villagers of Nanking help you?
The capital was invaded by the Japsen a few years ago. They jumped at the chance.
*ALARM*
Consider this an Übung to hone our skills to get my Studenten back! Nix kann uns in de Weg sitten!
@BATTLE
Once our captors removed the Studenten from my location, I was able to escape Nanking and flee to Schanghai to call for help. It takes fewer guards for a single person than for a whole Klasse.
I sent an Offizier to speak to a Repräsentanten from Mitsubishi.
What if they are not willing to cooperate?
Don't forget, we have our Artefaktdiebe to help us get the Studenten back.
Their captors might not respond well if we remove these children they've spent so much time and effort obtaining.
I wish people would have more Anstand about them. If they did, my Studenten wouldn't have been kidnapped in the first place.

Fields.MenuText: Let's see what the officer who is acting as liaison reports back with.
At this point, I trust that you know best.

Fields.DialogueText: Good idea, Kapitän. We can't afford to make any move too soon that would risk the lives of my Studenten.
I appreciate your trust, Kapitän. You have been a true Freund through all of this.
Here comes the lieutenant...
Lieutenant, what's the current situation?
Not good, Kapitän. The Repräsentant claims he's just a middle-man. Mitsubishi is eager to help us "resolve the difficulties" with their supplier by "facilitating communication."
Meine armen Studenten!
*ALARM*
This is by far the worst possible time for the Nixe to show up!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Why would a Japanese manufacturer have to kidnap a war ally's citizens in the first place?

Fields.DialogueText: Wer weiß das schon? We don't know if their Befehle come from on high or not. Perhaps Mitsubishi are thinking ahead to the next war.
We're going to have to do this the hard way.
You think it's them?
One of their suppliers, at any rate. We follow the Flugzeug, so to speak.
But it's not their fault and therefore it's our problem. Is that it?
That's the official line, ja.
Leutnant, I need to know the status of my Studenten.
Apparently, they're fine. However, it like actually the Japanische Armee is behind this. And they're unwilling to give them up unless we provide a magnetische paint light enough for Flugzeuge.
We would need to find a Chemiker who's willing to help us... which would be easier said than done. And even then, would such action be advisable?
Damn. They've got us every way we turn.
Giving them advanced technology after they've already committed such a horrible crime... it's asking for trouble.
What would you have me do, Schiffsdame Emden?
For now, tell them we will get them their Pläne.
But you just said...
They don't have to be the korrekte Pläne. They only need to believe they're real long enough for us to retrieve the Studenten.

Fields.MenuText: Ahh... a bit of subterfuge.
You certainly fooled me!
Time to bring out the heavy artillery!

Fields.DialogueText: Nipp un nau!
This gives me hope, Kapitän!
I'm unsure if you mean this in the metaphorischen or literal sense... perhaps you should pursue a hobby as a Kabarettist.
*ALARM*
You ready, Emden?
Jederzeit, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Where are we headed, Emden?
We are headed to the western coast of the Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika. There is a Chemiker there who is keen to assist us.
Really? How did you get a chemist on board so quickly?
His family is from Emden. As such, he considered it his duty to assist me.

Fields.MenuText: I somehow doubt it was as simple as that.
He's all right assisting a German Belle?
Do we know we can trust him?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, it took some persuading, but not too much. It's a very good cause.
We are united against a common Feind. And we're neutral as an INPF Schiff.
We do not. But I am willing to take a risk on a fellow Emder... especially one who crosses a Kontinent to make it possible.
Now that you've located your students, what are you going to do with the pigeons?
Eventually I'll sell them back to the people we bought them from in Germany. Trained, Kamera carrying Duuven are valuable right now.
I wonder what Morganas think of pigeons...
*ALARM*
Let's make sure they don't even need to.
@BATTLE
For now, I think they may still be useful to us.
The Chemiker, Dr. Waalkes, is on board, Kapitän!
I'm surprised he showed.
Ja. It's very brave.
And, glücklicherweise, he happened to be on leave when I talked to him.
His company makes adhesives, don't they? Hadn't you mentioned something about stealth and adhesives?
They make other things as well. Dr. Waalkes develops coatings for vehicles and floors. A coating for a Flugzeug shouldn't be too much trouble.

Fields.MenuText: The world seems smaller the more places I travel.
How does the chemist feel about being in this situation?
What's he asking?

Fields.DialogueText: This is one of the reasons why I enjoy travel, Kapitän. It's also very educating.
He too fears for the safety of my Studenten. Any decent Person would.
Surprisingly... nothing. He simply wants to know that the Studenten are safe.
If only my Studenten could be here now. Think of the lessons they could learn about Chemie.
We will get them back soon enough!
Your high spirits are welcome, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
The Nixe, on the other hand...
@BATTLE
Translating the chemist's work?
Into German, ja. This way the plan looks like believable secret German Technologie.
Do you think they'll buy it?
It's difficult to say at this point, but Dr. Waalkes assures me the basic formulations are plausible enough.
Do you know what the formula creates?
In theory, this Formel creates a lightweight Polymer.
And it absorbs the signals from detection systems?
On very close range tests, ja. However, in longer range tests, nein. Hopefully, it will fool them long enough to get my Studenten back.

Fields.MenuText: We really don't want to use force against human ships. Neutrality Fleet politics are complicated enough as it is.
I'm surprised there aren't more adhesive bandages on this ship.
How do you know so much about radio frequency and detection systems?

Fields.DialogueText: I understand, Kapitän.
They do make dressing minor wounds and scrapes easy.
To train my Mannschaft, I must be well versed in all of my Ausrüstung, Kapitän. Remember, education is the key.
*ALARM*
I just wish we could fool these Morganas for a little longer.
@BATTLE
As honest as you are, you're getting very good at deception.
The Lord doesn't require me to be honest to my adversaries, Kapitän. This falls more into the realm of a military Finte... I think I can live with it.
Leutnant Müller is delivering the schematics now, Kapitän.
Good work, Emden.
I can't wait to have my Studenten back. I've missed their bright faces.

Fields.MenuText: I can't wait for when the Morganas are our only problem.
Maybe next time we're in the United States, we can get some of our chemist's adhesive bandages?
And I'm sure you'll be pleased to put ships in bottles once again.

Fields.DialogueText: Once this is over, we will have a new appreciation for the feeling of Langewiel.
They would be useful to have, Kapitän. Our friends will still be in Kontakt once this is over.
More than ever, Kapitän. My Seele could use the therapeutic creativity it brings.
Schiffsdame Emden, there is a problem!
Mien Hart! I'm feeling palpitations. What is it, Leutnant?
The kidnappers took all the Papiere without hesitation.
But the Problem is...?
The Problem is... they're still refusing to give the Studenten back. I think they never intended on giving them back in the first place.
Then we must go to Japan's government.
... I'm getting very tired of playing this nicely.
Ik mutt mi henleggen.
@BATTLE
Save it. We've got company!
I threatened to. The Repräsentant just laughed and asked where our proof was.
Emden, are you all right?
I have such an overwhelming feeling of dread, Kapitän.
We tried... the world is full of such treachery. I can see why the Nixen are here.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure the thieves can help us retrieve the students.
Even the best plans fail sometimes. It's a learning process.
Don't give up! Your students are depending on you!

Fields.DialogueText: I need to seek redemption. I need to know that my Klasse will be safe even after I have them back.
Thank you for the kind words, Kapitän. Your development as a kindred Seele has grown.
Jawohl, Kapitän! I cannot give up. I am their Lehrerin, after all.
I know you'll come up with a plan to get them back. It's just matter of time.
While we have some time at our disposal, it's only for as long as those Pläne aren't proven false.
After that, will they just dispose of my Studenten? It's a risk I am not willing to take.
How long do you think we have?
*ALARM*
Not again!
Hm...
@BATTLE
Here's my Plan, Kapitän. We will have the Diebe break in and retrieve the Studenten. In all the confusion, our Duuven will get incontrovertible proof of malfeasance.
However, we still need time to escape from the Japanischen waters. With a head start, so we can get back to Germany where we are safe.
I'm listening.
Why don't we enlist the Nixen?
Excuse me?
Think of it this way. If you have one Wolfsrudel at your door, other Wolfsrudel will keep away.
So what are you saying?
We have the eleven run their Infiltration. Meanwhile we go around luring Nixen to the bay of Nagoya. I've already spoken to Blauauge.
That's the name of the thieves' leader?
That's korrekt.
I've been calling them something else this entire time.

Fields.MenuText: How are you planning on luring the Morganas?
I can't believe that I was calling that person Walter...
Do you think we could capture a Morgana?

Fields.DialogueText: I've formulated a Plan... it seems legitimate on Papier, but I am uncertain of how it will work in practice.
Not to his face, I hope.
I think holding a Nixecaptive would be more trouble than it's worth. No, Kapitän, we need only lead them by the Nase.
Nixen do dislike Schiffsdamen... we need some sort of decoy, something that will make Nixen think several Schiffsdamen have gathered nearby.
Off the coast of Nagoya?
No, no, the decoy would be too visible. We should find a group of Nixen somewhere in the Beringsee and work our way down the Küste of Japan.
What do you think the other Belles will say to this?
There might be some backlash over luring Nixen around... that's just in the Natur of the Sache.
I'm sure many Sowjetschiffsdamen can attest to upsetting established Institutionen and Normen.
*ALARM*
Here's our first Morgana!
Do we even need a lure?
@BATTLE
Thank goodness for intermediaries.
It sure is noisy in here!
I am having the Mannschaft create steel cutouts of Schiffe!
Emden, you know as well as anyone that steel is not a resource we can afford to waste.
But Stahl mimics the hull of a Schiff much more efficiently than Holz. Imagine this as hunting... hunting for Nixen.

Fields.MenuText: I might know a Belle or two who would enjoy this.
How are you going to get the steel cutouts to float?
How are we going to move these decoys thousands of miles?

Fields.DialogueText: Let me know who they are! I can create a scene in a Buddel for them!
They will be on Holzrümpfen.
We will pull the decoys around by rope. If the Nixen move in too quickly, we'll cut the line.
I am so pleased to see the Mannschaft participating in creating these decoys.
So just a cutout of a ship is good enough?
We will play recordings of various Schiffsdamen as well. Hopefully that will be enough to get the attention of the Nixen.
What if a non-Morgana ship sees all this as a threat?
The bloodthirsty Nixen will attack first. No mundane Schiff will dare to come close anyways.
*ALARM*
Everyone, pause your work! We have incoming Nixen to take care of!
@BATTLE
I'm not planning to lose it!
The decoys are in place. Start up the audio.
Why do I have butterflies in my stomach?
Is it from Vorfreude or Nervosität?

Fields.MenuText: Excitement, certainly excitement.
It's from nerves.
Probably a bit of both.

Fields.DialogueText: I am glad you are excited and not nervous. The lives of the Studenten are at risk.
Maybe have a drink to calm yourself, Kapitän?
Well, put the Fokus on the Vorfreude, would you?
Hey, those are my German optic binoculars! What are you doing with them?
Look, there's something at the Horizont already!
I would be able to look, but someone took my binoculars from me.
Ach ja. Here you go.
*ALARM*
Here we go. The first Morgana.
Now remember, the key is to have them follow us.
Right. We batter their vanguard, get some breathing room, and withdraw.
Simpel, oder?
@BATTLE
I can't believe this is working.
Don't hold your breath yet. I've dispersed Blauauge and the Rest. If the Plan works, we will rendezvous with them on the coast of Toyohashi.
And if they fail?
Then let's hope they enjoy the challenge of escaping prison. I wonder if Blue Eyes could make that great escape...

Fields.MenuText: These Morganas in tow make me nervous.
Can I go shoot a Morgana?
How strong is your Apfelwein? You don't seem nervous at all!

Fields.DialogueText: While the Nixen are close, we should take the time to study them. It's an opportunity to learn.
As tempting as that may be, we need as many alive as possible to release in the bay.
I might have distilled it and made Apfelbrand instead.
I will calm my excitement. Let me have a swig of that Apfelbrand.
Look, I think another Nixenflotille is trying their luck!
@BATTLE
Drop the anchor on the decoy and cut the line! Increase fuel to the engines. We need to leave!
Yes, let's leave while the Nixen are distracted.
I didn't know you rigged actual munitions on the decoys...
Well, I needed to fool the Nixen for as long as possible.
Lieutenant!
Ja, Kapitän?
Full speed to our charted course of Toyohashi.
Jawohl, Kapitän!

Fields.MenuText: I hear Toyohashi makes the best calligraphy brushes in all of Japan.
Are you excited to get your students back?
Off we go. What's your top speed?

Fields.DialogueText: Ist das so? I wonder if they bring me one with them.
There's no word on if Blauauge and the rest could sneak them out of Japan yet. We won't know until we get to the rendezvous point.
Twenty-nine and a half knots, Kapitän. Not as fast as some Schiffe, but faster than others.
*ALARM*
I thought the Morganas were distracted by the decoy.
There must have been some stragglers. Some Nixen are certainly faster than others.
@BATTLE
Emden, look at this dessert. It's a rice and coconut cake.
I can't eat at a time like this. I am waiting to see if my Studenten are safe!
Not even a tiny bite of dessert?
Not even that. It would go to waste.

Fields.MenuText: Where's that bottle of Apfelbrand? Maybe try to calm your nerves?
I'm sure everyone, including your students, will arrive shortly.
Less food for you is more food for the captain.

Fields.DialogueText: I drank it all when we were luring the Nixen earlier.
You are right, Kapitän. I must have faith.
Don't be too distracted, Kapitän. We must be vigilant.
There is a Nachen approaching, Schiffsdame Emden.
Let me have your Fernglas, Kapitän! I can't bear the wait.
I hope it's good news.
It's Blauauges Boot! I am heading down to see if my Studenten are safe!
Hold it! I don't need optics to see something's fishy...
Nixen! Our allies need help!
@BATTLE
My Studenten are safe again! Oh, how I've missed them...
They should be safe below. What's the word on our criminals?
Incriminating photos and documents are en route to the Japanischen Marineminister now. I expect Mitsubishi will assist in the investigation as well.
Those pigeons came in handy after all.
Indeed. Given the embarrassment... and the fact that Germany was willing to render aid... I daresay this ordeal has strengthened the relationship between our Reichen.

Fields.MenuText: I am glad you have your students back safe and sound!
Save some of those apple fritters for me!
You're doing your country a world of good.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke sehr, Kapitän! I couldn't have done it without you.
Better act fast, Kapitän!
Perhaps the world as well, Kapitän.
Now I can get back to focusing on battles and upgrading ships.
I do love a good Aufrüstung. And with the attention our project has received, it will get the Kooperation it deserves.
Think that'll fly in your country's lecture halls?
I know I am not the only Schiffsdame who feels this way. One way or another, I feel we will soon be impossible to ignore.
@BATTLE
What do you mean?
My first loyalty is to the Reich, Kapitän. But the Nixen should remind us of our common humanity too.
If one country makes a discovery, I hope they will have the generosity to share with the rest of the Klasse.
*ALARM*
The Morganas certainly don't ignore us.
We may learn even from them.
Where are we headed to now?
We need to drop these Studenten off at an undisclosed location until the war has cooled down.
I need to know where my ship is headed.
Natürlich, Kapitän. We are going to Buenos Aires and dropping them off there at a Universität where they can be safe. I've already arranged for the OKM to collect them there.

Fields.MenuText: Argentina sounds a rather interesting place for a group of German students.
I've never been to Argentina before.
I know Buenos Aires like the back of my hand!

Fields.DialogueText: It's far away from Japanischen Heerespionen in the INPF and any major war. As long as it remains undisclosed, they will be out of harm's way.
It's an interesting geographical location. I am certain my Studenten will learn quite a bit.
How wonderful! Wait here while I retrieve my Notizbuch to take notes. I am eager to learn about the Kultur.
Is now a good time for dessert?
You know me well, Kapitän.
